awd_titl_txt: Biophysical Mechanisms of Ultrasound Modulation of Cellular Functions in the MHz Domain
awd_abstract_narration:
The overarching aim of this project is to study the cellular bases of modulation of neuronal activity using ultrasound. Ultrasound is now becoming recognized as an important new modality for noninvasively modulating neuronal functions in the brain because: (a) a focused beam can be applied noninvasively from outside the head to any region of the brain, even deep in the brain within a very small region (1-3 mm in Full Width Half Maximum (FWHM) for a 1 Megahertz (MHz) ultrasound beam); and because (b) Ultrasound can be used to safely modulate neuronal activity within the FDA safety limit. This project will examine two mechanisms of neuromodulation that are still hardly investigated, the modulation of membrane capacitance Cm and conductance gm associated with the lipid bilayer of the cell membranes, in an isolated giant axon of the crayfish. This project has broad impact in three areas: (1) It will pave a way to study the biophysics of the ionic channels and lipid membranes in the MHz domain, thereby providing insights into the kinetics of single ion channels that open and close in a millisecond scale; (2) It will provide the foundation for using ultrasound as a new modality for tomographic neuroimaging with a millimeter and a millisecond resolution that is just beginning to be investigated by this group and perhaps others; and (3) It will provide a specific new mechanism for opening the blood-brain barrier with important implications in drug delivery.
 
Ultrasound (US) can modulate Cm by either the cavitation or radiation force. When a pressure wave of US hits the membrane, its cavitation force is thought to expand, oscillate or collapse gas bodies in the tissue or solution around it, deforming the bilayer geometry in synchrony with the period of ultrasound and thereby modulating Cm. Ultrasound can also alter Cm by mechanically moving the membrane due to the radiation force caused by spatial gradients in acoustic intensity. Empirically, the radiation force can produce strong clearly detectable capacitive current across a synthesized lipid bilayer at the onset and offset of a train of ultrasound pulses. The PIs will study the modulation of Cm by the cavitation force. This mechanism has not been studied experimentally in biological preparations, in comparison to the effect of the radiation force on Cm, even though simulation studies imply that this type of modulation should produce very strong intracellular currents.

por.por_cntn:
Ultrasound is a technique that has become very useful as a noninvasive imaging method for visualizing structures of internal organs such as the breast or heart, for measuring speed of fluid movement such as blood flow, and for measuring movement of parts of the organs that move such as movement of valves in the heart and movement of the heart muscles. In addition to imaging, ultrasound is becoming a useful method treating neurological disorders, for example in treating patients with Parkinson’s disease or essential tremor.

Our project (NSF grant 1707865: Biophysical mechanisms of ultrasound modulation of cellular functions in the MHz domain) has focused on yet another direction of development, ultrasound as a technique for neuromodulation and neuroimaging. This is a relatively new direction. It has been receiving attention in the scientific community during the past decade. It is becoming clear that focused ultrasound (FUS) can be used to modulate neuronal activity. FUS can affect activity in different regions of the brain including the cerebral cortex and subcortical regions. Within the cerebral cortex, FUS can modulate activity in the motor areas and sensory areas in primates and humans. As FUS becomes a new neuromodulation technique, there are needs to understand the mechanisms by which FUS may affect neuronal activity.

In our project, we initially used a simplified neuronal preparation, an isolated motor axon and neuromuscular junction of crayfish, in order to discover the mechanisms at a single cell level. We found FUS invariably produces membrane hyperpolarization, FUS-evoked hyperpolarization or FUSH, when the pressure of FUS is relatively low. Although we have not conclusively determined the mechanism, our results indicate that this phenomenon of hyperpolarization is due to modulation of capacitance of the cell membrane (Cm) produced by cavitational force in the gap that exists between two layers in the bilayer lipid membrane. The cavitational force expands the space between the two layers, reducing Cm, which then hyperpolarizes the membrane potential (Yu et al., 2023).

As the pressure of FUS is increased, the membrane switches from hyperpolarization to depolarization. When the pressure is strong enough, the depolarization becomes strong enough for the axon to fire one or more action potentials (Lin et al., 2019).

When and only when the FUS depolarizes the membrane, the conductance of the membrane gm increases (Lin et al., 2019). We determined that this increase in conductance is due to opening of a nonselective conductance gUS, specifically opened by FUS.  It can open as quickly as in <1 ms. Once open, the conductance may be elevated for a few milliseconds or even 20 sec or longer. This is to the best of our knowledge a novel type of conductance specifically opened by FUS.

We also determined that FUS can influence not only properties of the lipid bilayer, but also properties of voltage-gated channels (VGCs). The action potentials increased in amplitude and duration, but the delay was not affected by FUS (Yu, PhD thesis, 2022, unpublished).

We also found that FUS can modulate neuronal transmission. In an isolated neuromuscular junction preparation of Drosophila, FUS reduced synaptic delay in the neuronal transmission, which was expressed as shorter delay in excitatory junction potential (Alshuaib et al, Society for Neuroscience Poster, 2023).

We expanded the scope of our NSF project to include an in vivo investigation in order to apply the knowledge we have started to gain from our in vitro work. During the last year of the regular cycle of funding and during the period of no cost extension, we showed that FUS can directly activate neurons in the primary somatosensory cortex of rat in vivo. Application of a beam of FUS onto the exposed barrel cortex of the rat produced short latency components that have not been reported previously. The components consist of a train of spikes within a latency range of 1.2 ms to 6 ms and a wave starting at around 6 ms and ending at around 12 ms with a peak occurring between 8 and 10 ms. These two components occur before the large component peaking between 20 and 30 ms, which we had seen in our earlier study (Tripathi et al., 2020). 

We have used the insights from our in vitro studies to formulate hypotheses as to the mechanisms producing these components.  We know that all of these components are neuronal in origin by showing that their amplitudes are affected by the inter-burst interval (IBI) between repetitions of bursts of FUS. The maximum suppression is seen with an IBI of 10-20 ms for the the spike train and the slower wave peaking between 8-10 ms. These components may be mediated by the faster GABA-A inhibitory system.
